summary: Anaplastic thyroid cancer (ATC) is a rare, aggressive form of thyroid cancer characterized by uncontrolled growth of highly abnormal cells in the thyroid gland. It accounts for a small percentage of thyroid cancer cases but is responsible for a significant proportion of deaths due to its aggressive behavior, rapid growth, and resistance to many standard cancer treatments. ATC typically carries a very poor prognosis, with a median survival time of three to six months after diagnosis. It often presents as a rapidly enlarging neck mass and can cause symptoms by compressing local structures.
risk_factors: Exposure to certain types of radiation (e.g., radiation treatments to head or neck as a child, radiation emergency, repeated radiation exposure to chest or neck)
Certain genetic conditions (e.g., multiple endocrine neoplasia)
Family history of thyroid cancer or thyroid disease
symptoms: Redness and swelling of overlying skin
diagnosis: Physical exam (checking neck for swelling, lumps)
Immunohistochemistry testing (e.g., positive for keratin, p53, PAX8; negative for thyroid transcription factor-1, thyroglobulin, calcitonin)
Ultrasound imaging (hypoechoic mass, invasion of local structures, lymph node metastases)
Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CT) scan of the neck
CT scan of the neck, chest, abdomen, and pelvis (for staging)
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the brain (to assess for distant metastases)
treatments: Surgery (often unresectable, but curative if resectable and followed by adjuvant therapy)
Combinatorial therapy (molecular-based, targeted therapies, immunotherapy, surgery)
